title: Are YOU brave enough to contact the dead? TV ghost hunter Ian Lawman claims to have found spirits in the deepest, darkest reaches of central London's creepiest spot

TV psychic Ian Lawman (pictured, middle) claims to have found a number of spine-chilling spirit residents in London's historic County Hall
The first ghost-busting investigation ever to be conducted in London's historic County Hall - home of the famous London Dungeon tourist attraction - claims to have dug up the spirits of a Victorian doctor, singing urchin children, and potentially even the ghost of Jack The Ripper - the capital's most notorious serial killer.
TV psychic Ian Lawman confirmed that the ancient building's darkest corners are haunted by a number of spine-chilling spirit residents while sneaking around the century old property on an exclusive probe aimed at finally discovering the vast old building's spine-chilling secrets.
Needless to say the amateur team - of which this reporter was part - were scared witless as the exorcist brought us face-to-face with the undead when he then sat us down for a nerve-shredding séance.
The session, which was a popular way of communicating with spirits in the Victorian times, involved sitting around a table, connecting pinky fingers while Lawman called on the ghosts to come forward.
We experienced chilling drops in temperature, racing heartbeats, choking sensations and the feeling of being unable to move, as we joined the famed paranormal investigator in contacting the other side.
Several of the group even experienced the feeling of being in the presence of young children, with Lawman confirming a sighting of the spirit of Florence Cook and a mysterious long-bearded doctor.

His assertion of the number of spirits roaming the halls of County Hall - in which the London Dungeons is the deepest part - just ramps up further the genuinely terrifying nature of the attraction's heart-stopping séances, running all this month.
Lawman, star of the UK's cult series Most Haunted and his own Famous and Frightened show, said: 'There is undoubtedly an abundance of spiritual activity in County Hall and we had a number of vivid experiences, some involving the spirits of children of whom I felt there were many in the building.
The master medium took a team on his invesitgation into the 100-year-old building - and needless to say they were scared witless. The exorcist brought them face-to-face with the undead during a nerve-shredding séance inside the London Dungeon
'In one of the rooms somebody could hear children screaming and another member of the group felt a child hold their hand for the entire time.
'This same child, a boy of six or seven, came through to us in our séance, along with a young girl. Their presence strongly affected one of the group who could feel a child sitting on their lap.
'The children were poor, raggedly dressed and I'd place them in the early Victorian period. Although wretched they weren't unhappy and like most children that age, were curious to see what was going on.'
The session, which was a popular way of communicating with spirits in the Victorian times, involved sitting around a table, connecting pinky fingers while Lawman called on the ghosts to come forward
One woman, Gemma Mullin (centre), was left petrified when Ian (left) revealed that the cold feeling she was experiencing on her legs and midriff was in fact the ghost of an urchin child sitting on her lap
The séance room is situated immediately over a sub-basement corridor where a number of London Dungeon staff have reported spooky experiences of their own in the past.
The Dungeon is now extending an invite to the capital's bravest souls to take a seat at any of their special Halloween séances, being held in what has now been confirmed as the most haunted address in town.
Back-from-the-dead Victorian medium Florence Cook is taking up residence for a chilling season connecting directly with the long departed in a paranormal investigation guaranteed to make even the most hardened disbelievers' hair stand on end.
The truly terrifying round-table rendezvous will see all hell break loose as the most celebrated medium of the era whisks guests back to the city's most haunted house.
The ghost-hunting investigation through County Hall also left Ian's guests paralysed with fear. Chilling drops in temperature, racing heartbeats, choking sensations and the feeling of being unable to move were all reported
Several of the group even experienced the feeling of being in the presence of young children, with Lawman confirming a sighting of the spirit of Florence Cook and a mysterious long-bearded doctor
The Dungeon is now extending an invite to the capital's bravest souls to take a seat at any of their special Halloween séances
Séance! is set in 1873 and based entirely on real events. Guests will find themselves transported to 50 Berkley Square as Miss Cook - famed as the medium who claimed to materialise the spirit of Katie King - prepares for her latest sitting.
Dare they enter the séance chamber and witness Cook's communion with her ghostly spirit guide?
Or will the supernatural disturbances in the ante-room send them fleeing into the night?
That's for the creatures of the night to decide. But if last week's pre-launch paranormal investigation by Lawman is anything to go by, there's plenty coming back to life in the deepest, darkest reaches of central London's creepiest spot.
TRAVEL FACTS Tickets for the séance must be booked in advance. To find out more and to book visit www.thedungeons.com/london
